options.D: Media backups are performed on a timely basis and stored offsite.

questions.explanation: Ensuring that media backups are performed regularly and stored offsite is essential for data recovery after a disaster. Without these backups, other recovery efforts would be ineffective.

questions.questionText: Question: The PRIMARY objective of business continuity and disaster recovery plans should be to:

options.C: Minimize the loss to an organization.

questions.explanation: The primary objective of any disaster recovery or business continuity plan is to protect human life, as it is the highest priority in any emergency situation.

questions.questionText: Question: After a full operational contingency test, an IS auditor performs a review of the recovery steps. The auditor concludes that the time it took for the technological environment and systems to return to full- functioning exceeded the required critical recovery time. Which of the following should the auditor recommend?

options.A: Perform an integral review of the recovery tasks.
options.B: Broaden the processing capacity to gain recovery time.
options.C: Make improvements in the facility's circulation structure.
options.D: Increase the amount of human resources involved in the recovery.

questions.explanation: Performing an exhaustive review of the recovery tasks would be appropriate to identify where delays occurred and which tasks need to be adjusted to meet the recovery time objective.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is a continuity plan test that uses actual resources to simulate a system crash to cost-effectively obtain evidence about the plan's effectiveness?
questions.explanation: A preparedness test is a localized version of a full test, wherein resources are expended in the simulation of a system crash. This test is performed regularly on different aspects of the plan and can be a cost-effective way to gradually obtain evidence about the plan's effectiveness.

questions.questionText: Question: While designing the business continuity plan (BCP) for an airline reservation system, the MOST appropriate method of data transfer/backup at an offsite location would be:
questions.explanation: In shadow file processing, exact duplicates of the files are maintained at the same site or at a remote site. The two files are processed concurrently. This is used for critical data files, such as airline booking systems.

questions.questionText: Question: Depending on the complexity of an organization's business continuity plan (BCP), the plan may be developed as a set of more than one plan to address various aspects of business continuity and disaster recovery, in such an environment, it is essential that:

options.A: Each plan is consistent with one another.
options.B: All plans are integrated into a single plan.
options.C: Each plan is dependent on one another.
options.D: The sequence for implementation of all plans is defined.

questions.explanation: Depending on the complexity of an organization, there could be more than one plan to address various aspects of business continuity and disaster recovery. These do not necessarily have to be integrated into one single plan. However, each plan has to be consistent with others to have a viable business continuity.

questions.questionText: Question: During a business continuity audit an IS auditor found that the business continuity plan (BCP) covered only critical processes. The IS auditor should:

options.A: Recommend that the BCP cover all business processes.
options.B: Assess the impact of the processes not covered.
options.C: Report the findings to the IT manager.

questions.explanation: The business impact analysis needs to be either updated or revisited to assess the risk of not covering all processes in the plan. It is possible that the cost of including all processes might exceed the value of those processes; therefore, they should not be covered.

questions.questionText: Question: An IS auditor noted that an organization had adequate business continuity plans (BCPs) for each individual process, but no comprehensive BCP. Which would be the BEST course of action for the IS auditor?

options.A: Recommend that an additional comprehensive BCP be developed.
options.B: Determine whether the BCPs are consistent.
options.D: Recommend the creation of a single BCP.

questions.explanation: It is essential that the individual plans for each department or process are consistent with each other. There is no immediate need to combine them into one comprehensive plan unless inconsistencies or gaps are identified.

questions.questionText: Question: When developing a business continuity plan (BCP), which of the following tools should be used to gain an understanding of the organization's business processes?
questions.explanation: A risk assessment helps to identify potential threats and impacts to the organization, providing a basis for understanding business processes and their vulnerability in the event of a disaster.

questions.questionText: Question: During an audit of a business continuity plan (BCP), an IS auditor found that, although all departments were housed in the same building, each department had a separate BCP. The IS auditor recommended that the BCPs be reconciled. Which of the following areas should be reconciled FIRST?
questions.explanation: The safety of human resources is the highest priority during any disaster. Reconciling evacuation plans ensures that there are no conflicts in how employees and other personnel will be evacuated from the building.

questions.questionText: Question: Management considered two projections for its business continuity plan; plan A with two months to recover and plan B with eight months to recover. The recovery objectives are the same in both plans. It is reasonable to expect that plan B projected higher:
questions.explanation: Since the recovery time is longer in plan B, the downtime costs will likely be higher due to prolonged business disruptions.

questions.questionText: Question: The optimum business continuity strategy for an entity is determined by the:

options.A: Lowest downtime cost and highest recovery cost.
options.B: Lowest sum of downtime cost and recovery cost.
options.C: Lowest recovery cost and highest downtime cost.
options.D: Average of the combined downtime and recovery cost.

questions.explanation: The best strategy balances the lowest downtime and recovery costs to minimize overall disruption and expenses.

questions.questionText: Question: The PRIMARY objective of testing a business continuity plan is to:

options.A: Familiarize employees with the business continuity plan.
options.B: Ensure that all residual risks are addressed.
options.D: Identify limitations of the business continuity plan.

questions.explanation: The main goal of testing a BCP is to identify its limitations, ensuring that any flaws or gaps are discovered and addressed.

questions.questionText: Question: In determining the acceptable time period for the resumption of critical business processes:

options.A: Only downtime costs need to be considered.
options.C: Both downtime costs and recovery costs need to be evaluated.
options.D: Indirect downtime costs should be ignored.

questions.explanation: Both downtime and recovery costs must be evaluated to determine a reasonable recovery time for critical business processes. Indirect costs, like reputational damage, should also be factored into the assessment.

questions.questionText: Question: In the event of a disruption or disaster, which of the following technologies provides for continuous operations?
questions.explanation: Fault-tolerant hardware is specifically designed to ensure continuous operation without interruption, even in the case of component failures.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following would be MOST important for an IS auditor to verify when conducting a business continuity audit?

options.A: Data backups are performed on a timely basis
options.B: A recovery site is contracted for and available as needed
options.C: Human safety procedures are in place
options.D: Insurance coverage is adequate and premiums are current

questions.explanation: The protection of human life is the most critical element in any business continuity plan, making human safety procedures the top priority during an audit.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following insurance types provide for a loss arising from fraudulent acts by employees?
questions.explanation: Fidelity insurance specifically covers losses resulting from fraudulent or dishonest acts committed by employees.

questions.questionText: Question: The BEST method for assessing the effectiveness of a business continuity plan is to review the:

options.A: Plans and compare them to appropriate standards.

questions.explanation: Reviewing the results of previous tests provides the best evidence of the plan's effectiveness in real disaster recovery situations.

questions.questionText: Question: With respect to business continuity strategies, an IS auditor interviews key stakeholders in an organization to determine whether they understand their roles and responsibilities. The IS auditor is attempting to evaluate the:

options.A: Clarity and simplicity of the business continuity plans.
options.B: Adequacy of the business continuity plans.
options.C: Effectiveness of the business continuity plans.
options.D: Ability of IS and end-user personnel to respond effectively in emergencies.

questions.explanation: The IS auditor's goal is to ensure that all stakeholders understand their roles in the event of a disaster, which reflects the clarity and simplicity of the business continuity plan.

questions.questionText: Question: During the design of a business continuity plan, the business impact analysis (BIA) identifies critical processes and supporting applications. This will PRIMARILY influence the:

options.A: Responsibility for maintaining the business continuity plan.
options.B: Criteria for selecting a recovery site provider.

questions.explanation:
The most appropriate strategy is selected based on the relative risk level and criticality identified in the
business impact analysis (BIA). The other choices are made after the selection or design of the appropriate recovery strategy.

questions.questionText: Question: During a review of a business continuity plan, an IS auditor noticed that the point at which a situation is declared to be a crisis has not been defined. The MAJOR risk associated with this is that:

options.A: Assessment of the situation may be delayed.
options.B: Execution of the disaster recovery plan could be impacted.
options.C: Notification of the teams might not occur.
options.D: Potential crisis recognition might be ineffective.

questions.explanation: Execution of the business continuity plan would be impacted if the organization does not know when to declare a crisis. Choices A, C, and D are steps that must be performed to know whether to declare a crisis. Problem and severity assessment would provide information necessary in declaring a disaster.

questions.questionText: Question: An organization has just completed their annual risk assessment. Regarding the business continuity plan, what should an IS auditor recommend as the next step for the organization?

options.A: Review and evaluate the business continuity plan for adequacy.
options.B: Perform a full simulation of the business continuity plan.
options.C: Train and educate employees regarding the business continuity plan.
options.D: Notify critical contacts in the business continuity plan.

questions.explanation: The business continuity plan should be reviewed every time a risk assessment is completed for the organization. Training of the employees and a simulation should be performed after the business continuity plan has been deemed adequate for the organization.

questions.questionText: Question: Integrating business continuity planning (BCP) into an IT project aids in:

options.A: The retrofitting of the business continuity requirements.
options.B: The development of a more comprehensive set of requirements.
options.C: The development of a transaction flowchart.
options.D: Ensuring the application meets the user's needs.

questions.explanation: Integrating business continuity planning (BCP) into the development process ensures complete coverage of the requirements through each phase of the project. Retrofitting of the business continuity plan's requirements occurs when BCP is not integrating into the development methodology.

questions.questionText: Question: The activation of an enterprise's business continuity plan should be based on predetermined criteria that address the:
questions.explanation: The initiation of a business continuity plan (action) should primarily be based on the maximum period for which a business function can be disrupted before the disruption threatens the achievement of organizational objectives.

questions.questionText: Question: An IS auditor can verify that an organization's business continuity plan (BCP) is effective by reviewing the:

options.A: Alignment of the BCP with industry best practices.
options.B: Results of business continuity tests performed by IS and end-user personnel.
options.C: Off-site facility, its contents, security, and environmental controls.
options.D: Annual financial cost of the BCP activities versus the expected benefit of implementation of the plan.

questions.explanation: The effectiveness of the business continuity plan (BCP) can best be evaluated by reviewing the results from previous business continuity tests for thoroughness and accuracy in accomplishing their stated objectives.

questions.questionText: Question: To optimize an organization's business contingency plan (BCP), an IS auditor should recommend conducting a business impact analysis (BIA) in order to determine:

options.A: The business processes that generate the most financial value for the organization and therefore must be recovered first.
options.B: The priorities and order for recovery to ensure alignment with the organization's business strategy.
options.C: The business processes that must be recovered following a disaster to ensure the organization's survival.
options.D: The priorities and order of recovery which will recover the greatest number of systems in the shortest time frame.

questions.explanation: To ensure the organization's survival following a disaster, it is important to recover the most critical business processes first. The BIA helps prioritize recovery based on critical business functions.

questions.questionText: Question: A financial services organization is developing and documenting business continuity measures. In which of the following cases would an IS auditor MOST likely raise an issue?

options.A: The organization uses good practice guidelines instead of industry standards and relies on external advisors to ensure the adequacy of the methodology.
options.B: The business continuity capabilities are planned around a carefully selected set of scenarios which describe events that might happen with a reasonable probability.
options.C: The recovery time objectives (RTOs) do not take IT disaster recovery constraints into account, such as personnel or system dependencies during the recovery phase.
options.D: The organization plans to rent a shared alternate site with emergency workplaces which has only enough room for half of the normal staff.

questions.explanation: It is a common mistake to use scenario planning for business continuity. Planning for just selected scenarios denies the fact that even improbable events can cause an organization to break down.

questions.questionText: Question: A medium-sized organization, whose IT disaster recovery measures have been in place and regularly tested for years, has just developed a formal business continuity plan (BCP). A basic BCP tabletop exercise has been performed successfully. Which testing should an IS auditor recommend be performed NEXT to verify the adequacy of the new BCP?

options.A: Full-scale test with relocation of all departments, including IT, to the contingency site.
options.B: Walk-through test of a series of predefined scenarios with all critical personnel involved.
options.C: IT disaster recovery test with business departments involved in testing the critical applications.
options.D: Functional test of a scenario with limited IT involvement.

questions.explanation: After a tabletop exercise, the next step would be a functional test, which includes the mobilization of staff to exercise the administrative and organizational functions of a recovery.

questions.questionText: Question: Everything not explicitly permitted is forbidden has which of the following kinds of tradeoff?

options.A: It improves security at a cost in functionality.
options.B: It improves functionality at a cost in security.
options.C: It improves security at a cost in system performance.
options.D: It improves performance at a cost in functionality.

questions.explanation: "Everything not explicitly permitted is forbidden (default deny) improves security at a cost in functionality."

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is the MOST important reason for conducting periodic reviews of business continuity plans?

options.A: To verify that business continuity arrangements are still in line with business goals.
options.B: To ensure that the plan is updated to reflect changes in the organization.
options.C: To ensure that recovery time objectives (RTOs) meet industry standards.
options.D: To ensure that a detailed disaster recovery test is scheduled.

questions.explanation: A periodic review is essential to make sure the business continuity plan reflects any changes in business processes, technologies, or organizational structure. This ensures that the plan is current and effective.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following would MOST likely be included in a business continuity plan's recovery strategies?

options.A: The identification of critical applications and business functions.
options.B: The type and number of alternate facilities for recovery.
options.C: The cost of procuring backup software for recovery.
options.D: The selection of personnel for disaster recovery.

questions.explanation: Recovery strategies typically include planning for alternative work locations, IT resources, and other physical and personnel needs to ensure business continuity in the event of an emergency.

questions.questionText: Question: In the event of a data breach, the IS auditor's FIRST priority should be to:

options.B: Ensure that the breach is contained and the source is identified.
options.C: Assess the magnitude of the breach and its impact.

questions.explanation: The primary objective is to understand the scope and impact of the breach to determine the necessary response. Containment and identification of the source should follow as part of the response strategy.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is the BEST way to ensure that a business continuity plan (BCP) is effective?

options.A: Regularly test and update the BCP to reflect changes in the business environment.
options.B: Assign responsibility for testing the BCP to the IT department.
options.C: Involve all departments in the BCP testing process.
options.D: Assign recovery objectives and criticality ratings to all departments.

questions.explanation: Involving all departments in the testing process ensures that the business continuity plan covers all aspects of the organization and that all areas are prepared for a real recovery scenario.

questions.questionText: Question: A financial institution has a business continuity plan (BCP) that outlines the recovery of critical business functions and systems. The NEXT step in ensuring the recovery process is complete would be to:

options.A: Test and validate the recovery procedures through simulations.
options.B: Review the BCP to identify potential gaps in the recovery process.
options.C: Conduct a full-scale disaster recovery test.
options.D: Notify all stakeholders of the recovery procedures.

questions.explanation: A full-scale disaster recovery test helps verify whether the entire recovery process can be executed successfully under real-world conditions, ensuring that all functions are properly restored.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is the MOST critical step in developing an effective business continuity plan (BCP)?

options.C: Assigning disaster recovery responsibilities to staff.

questions.explanation: The Business Impact Analysis (BIA) is the foundational step in BCP because it helps identify the most critical business functions and their dependencies, forming the basis for the continuity plan.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is the PRIMARY concern when selecting a backup site for disaster recovery?

options.A: The proximity of the site to the organization's primary location.
options.C: The number of staff available at the site.
options.D: The type of disaster the site is designed to recover from.

questions.explanation: Proximity is crucial because the site needs to be close enough to minimize downtime and distance-related challenges during recovery. However, it should still be far enough to avoid the same impact from regional disasters.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is MOST important when conducting a business continuity plan (BCP) tabletop exercise?

options.A: Ensuring all departments participate in the exercise.
options.B: Ensuring that IT systems are tested under real-world conditions.
options.C: Reviewing the technical aspects of the disaster recovery plan.
options.D: Evaluating the cost of disaster recovery procedures.

questions.explanation: The success of a tabletop exercise depends on the involvement of all relevant departments. It helps ensure that the entire organization is prepared for recovery, not just the IT department.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following actions is MOST effective in preventing unauthorized access to critical systems in an organization?

options.B: Restricting user access to read-only mode.
options.C: Assigning different levels of access based on job roles.

questions.explanation: Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is one of the most effective methods for preventing unauthorized access by requiring multiple forms of identification.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following strategies is MOST effective for ensuring that an organization's critical data is protected from a ransomware attack?

options.A: Encrypting all sensitive data at rest and in transit.
options.B: Using backup systems to store data off-site.
options.C: Implementing strong access controls and segmenting networks.

questions.explanation: Strong access controls and network segmentation help limit the attack surface and prevent ransomware from spreading across critical systems. Backups and encryption are also important, but segmentation provides an additional layer of security.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following would MOST likely indicate the need to review an organization's business continuity plan (BCP)?

options.A: The organization changes its IT systems.
options.B: The organization experiences high turnover in IT staff.
options.C: The organization moves to a new office location.
options.D: The organization undergoes a significant merger or acquisition.

questions.explanation: A merger or acquisition often leads to changes in organizational structure, processes, and priorities, making it essential to review and potentially update the business continuity plan to ensure that it aligns with the new organization.

questions.questionText: Question: TEMPEST is hardware for which of the following purposes?
questions.explanation: TEMPEST refers to the monitoring of electromagnetic emissions from hardware to intercept data, even in closed systems. It is commonly associated with eavesdropping on data transmitted by electronic devices.

questions.questionText: Question: Human error is being HEAVILY relied upon by which of the following types of attack?
questions.explanation: Social engineering attacks exploit human errors, such as deception or manipulation, to gain access to systems or sensitive information.

questions.questionText: Question: Zombie computers are being HEAVILY relied upon by which of the following types of attack?
questions.explanation: In Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, a large number of compromised "zombie" computers are used to flood a target system with requests, overwhelming it and causing service disruption.

questions.questionText: Question: Attack amplifier is often being HEAVILY relied upon by which of the following types of attack?
questions.explanation: In DDoS attacks, an attack amplifier exploits third-party systems with poorly designed protocols to amplify the attack, resulting in a flood of traffic directed at the target.

questions.questionText: Question: Back Orifice is an example of:

options.C: A backdoor that takes the form of an installed program

questions.explanation: Back Orifice is a type of backdoor that can be installed on a system to allow unauthorized remote access. It can also be used to monitor activities and compromise security.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following will replace system binaries and/or hook into the function calls of the operating system to hide the presence of other programs?
questions.explanation: Rootkits are malicious programs designed to modify system binaries or hook into OS functions to hide the presence of other malicious software, making detection more difficult.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following types of attack almost always requires physical access to the targets?
questions.explanation: Direct access attacks require physical access to the target system in order to install malicious software, modify settings, or extract data.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following methods of encryption has been proven to be almost unbreakable when correctly used?
questions.explanation: The one-time pad is a theoretically unbreakable encryption method when used correctly, relying on a key that is as long as the message itself and used only once.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following encryption methods uses a matching pair of key-codes, securely distributed, which are used once-and-only-once to encode and decode a single message?
questions.explanation: The one-time pad encryption method uses a unique pair of key-codes, securely distributed and used only once to encrypt and decrypt a message, ensuring perfect secrecy when properly applied.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following measures can protect systems files and data, respectively?

options.A: User account access controls and cryptography
options.B: User account access controls and firewall
options.C: User account access controls and IPS

questions.explanation:
User account access controls protect system files by managing who can access them, while
cryptography can protect the data from unauthorized access or tampering.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is by far the most common prevention system from a network security perspective?
questions.explanation: The firewall is the most common network security prevention system, blocking unauthorized access and monitoring traffic based on predefined security rules.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following are designed to detect network attacks in progress and assist in post-attack forensics?
questions.explanation: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) detect network attacks as they occur and help with post-attack forensic analysis to understand the attack's origin and impact.

questions.questionText: Question: "Nowadays, computer security comprises mainly "preventive" measures."
questions.explanation: Modern computer security primarily involves preventive measures like firewalls, which help protect systems before an attack occurs.

questions.questionText: Question: ALL computer programming languages are vulnerable to command injection attack.
questions.explanation: Not all programming languages are susceptible to command injection. For example, languages like Java mitigate certain vulnerabilities but are still vulnerable to code and command injection in specific cases.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following refers to an anomalous condition where a process attempts to store data beyond the boundaries of a fixed length buffer?
questions.explanation: A buffer overflow occurs when a process attempts to write more data to a fixed-length buffer than it can hold, potentially overwriting adjacent memory and causing system crashes or vulnerabilities.

questions.questionText: Question: Buffer overflow aims primarily at corrupting:
questions.explanation: Buffer overflow attacks primarily target system memory, where the overflow can overwrite critical data and lead to program malfunctions or security breaches.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following measures can effectively minimize the possibility of buffer overflows?
questions.explanation: Performing sufficient bounds checking ensures that data written to a buffer does not exceed its allocated size, helping to prevent buffer overflow vulnerabilities.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following types of attack makes use of unfiltered user input as the format string parameter in the printf() function of the C language?
questions.explanation:
Format string vulnerabilities arise when unfiltered user input is used as the format string parameter
in functions like printf(). Malicious input can exploit this vulnerability to print data from memory or execute arbitrary code.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following kinds of function are particularly vulnerable to format string attacks?

options.A: C functions that perform output formatting
options.B: C functions that perform integer computation
options.C: C functions that perform real number subtraction
options.D: VB functions that perform integer conversion
options.E: SQL functions that perform string conversion
options.F: SQL functions that perform text conversion

questions.explanation: C functions that perform output formatting, like printf(), are particularly vulnerable to format string attacks, as these functions handle user-provided data in ways that can be exploited.

questions.questionText: Question: Integer overflow occurs primarily with:
questions.explanation: Integer overflow typically occurs during arithmetic operations when a value exceeds the maximum size that can be stored in a variable, leading to unexpected behavior or vulnerabilities.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following types of attack works by taking advantage of the unenforced and unchecked assumptions the system makes about its inputs?
questions.explanation: Code injection takes advantage of unchecked assumptions the system makes about its inputs. Attackers can inject malicious code into a program's input fields to execute arbitrary commands.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following terms refers to systems designed to detect and prevent the unauthorized transmission of information from the computer systems of an organization to outsiders?
questions.explanation: ILD&P (Information Leakage Detection and Prevention) systems are designed to detect and prevent unauthorized transmission of sensitive information from an organization's systems to outsiders, ensuring data security.

questions.questionText: Question: Network ILD&P are typically installed:

options.A: On the organization's internal network connection.
options.B: On the organization's internet network connection.

questions.explanation: Network ILD&P systems are typically installed on the organization's internet network connection. These systems analyze traffic to detect unauthorized information transmissions.

questions.questionText: Question: Host Based ILD&P primarily addresses the issue of:
questions.explanation: Host-Based ILD&P systems are focused on preventing information leakage by monitoring and controlling access to data before it leaves the organization.

questions.questionText: Question: Software is considered malware based on:
questions.explanation: Malware is defined by the intent of the creator, not by the software's features. Its goal is to damage, infiltrate, or gain unauthorized access to systems, typically without the owner's consent.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following refers to any program that invites the user to run it but conceals a harmful or malicious payload?
questions.explanation: A Trojan horse is a program that appears to be legitimate or harmless but secretly contains malicious code designed to damage, steal information, or otherwise harm the system when executed.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following terms is used more generally for describing concealment routines in a malicious program?
questions.explanation: Rootkits are specialized malicious software tools designed to conceal the presence of harmful processes or files. They often prevent detection by system monitoring tools.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following refers to a method of bypassing normal system authentication procedures?
questions.explanation: A backdoor is a method for bypassing normal authentication procedures, often used by hackers to maintain remote access to a compromised system.

questions.questionText: Question: To install backdoors, hackers generally prefer to use:

options.A: Either Trojan horse or computer worm

questions.explanation: Hackers typically use Trojan horses or computer worms to install backdoors, which allow them to maintain access to a compromised system.

questions.questionText: Question: In order to coordinate the activity of many infected computers, attackers have used coordinating systems known as:
questions.explanation: Botnets are networks of infected computers (often called "zombies") controlled by attackers to perform coordinated actions like launching attacks or sending spam.

questions.questionText: Question: In a botnet, malbot logs into a particular type of system for making coordinated attack attempts. What type of system is this?
questions.explanation: In a botnet, the malbot (malicious bot) logs into a chat system (such as an IRC channel) to receive instructions from the attacker for coordinated actions.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following software tools is often used for stealing money from infected PC owner through taking control of the modem?
questions.explanation: A porn dialer is malicious software that takes control of a user's modem to dial a premium-rate telephone number, incurring high charges for the infected user.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is an oft-cited cause of vulnerability of networks?
questions.explanation: Software monoculture refers to the reliance on a single software platform (like Windows), which makes systems vulnerable if that software is compromised. Attackers can exploit widespread software vulnerabilities, affecting large numbers of systems.

questions.questionText: Question: Introducing inhomogeneity to your network for the sake of robustness would have which of the following drawbacks?

options.D: High costs in terms of training and maintenance

questions.explanation: Introducing inhomogeneity (diversifying software or systems) increases costs due to the need for additional training and maintenance. While it may enhance security, it can also complicate management and increase operational overhead.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following may be deployed in a network as lower-cost surveillance and early-warning tools?
questions.explanation: Honeypots are decoy systems or resources set up to attract attackers. These are used for surveillance and early-warning, as they allow network administrators to study attack techniques and identify threats in real time.

questions.questionText: Question: All Social Engineering techniques are based on flaws in:
questions.explanation: Social engineering exploits flaws in human logic or cognitive biases. These flaws are manipulated to deceive individuals into revealing confidential information or performing actions that compromise security.

questions.questionText: Question: Relatively speaking, firewalls operated at the application level of the seven-layer OSI model are:

options.D: Almost always less costly to setup

questions.explanation: Firewalls that operate at the application level (Layer 7) are generally less efficient due to the heavy CPU processing required to analyze application data, compared to packet filtering firewalls that operate at lower layers.

questions.questionText: Question: Relatively speaking, firewalls operated at the physical level of the seven-layer OSI model are:

options.D: Almost always less costly to setup

questions.explanation: No firewalls operate at the physical level (Layer 1) of the OSI model, as firewalls typically function at higher layers such as Layer 3 (network layer) or Layer 7 (application layer).

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following refers to the act of creating and using an invented scenario to persuade a target to perform an action?
questions.explanation: Pretexting involves creating a fabricated scenario to persuade someone into disclosing information or performing an action that benefits the attacker. It often involves research or using known information to build trust.

questions.questionText: Question: Pretexting is an act of:
questions.explanation: Pretexting is a form of social engineering, where attackers create a fabricated story or scenario to manipulate individuals into disclosing information or taking certain actions.

questions.questionText: Question: With Deep Packet Inspection, which of the following OSI layers are involved?
questions.explanation: Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) examines the entire packet, including both the header and the data (payload), at layers 2 through 7 of the OSI model. This allows DPI to detect and filter packets based on more than just header information, such as protocols and content.

questions.questionText: Question: Squid is an example of:
questions.explanation: Squid is a caching proxy server that stores copies of frequently accessed web pages, reducing bandwidth usage and improving response time for users accessing the same content multiple times.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following types of firewall treats each network frame or packet in isolation?
questions.explanation: A stateless firewall examines each packet in isolation, without considering whether the packet is part of an ongoing session or connection, making it less aware of the context of traffic compared to stateful firewalls.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following types of attack involves a program that creates an infinite loop, makes lots of copies of itself, and continues to open lots of files?
questions.explanation: A Local DoS (Denial of Service) attack involves a program that creates an infinite loop, making many copies of itself and consuming system resources (like memory or CPU), which may lead to system unresponsiveness or crashes.

questions.questionText: Question: What is the best defense against Local DoS attacks?

options.D: Find this program and kill it

questions.explanation: In a Local DoS attack, a program creates an infinite loop or makes excessive copies of itself, consuming system resources. The best defense is to identify and kill the malicious program causing the DoS attack.

questions.questionText: Question: What is the best defense against Distributed DoS Attack?

options.D: Find the DoS program and kill it

questions.explanation:
For defending against Distributed DoS (DDoS) attacks, the best defense is to patch your systems
and ensure your firewalls are correctly configured to filter malicious traffic.

questions.questionText: Question: What is wrong with a Black Box type of intrusion detection system?

options.C: You cannot examine its internal workings from outside

questions.explanation: A Black Box Intrusion Detection System (IDS) is one where its internal workings are not visible to the user. This lack of transparency means it is difficult to examine or modify its internal processes, which can hinder troubleshooting and optimization.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following are often considered as the first defensive line in protecting a typical data and information environment?
questions.explanation: Passwords are the first line of defense for protecting data and information. They are used by users to authenticate their identity before accessing systems and resources.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following are the characteristics of a good password?

options.A: It has mixed-case alphabetic characters, numbers, and symbols
options.B: It has mixed-case alphabetic characters and numbers
options.C: It has mixed-case alphabetic characters and symbols
options.D: It has mixed-case alphabetic characters, numbers, and binary codes

questions.explanation: A good password should include mixed-case alphabetic characters, numbers, and symbols. This increases complexity and makes the password harder to guess or crack.

questions.questionText: Question: What is the recommended minimum length of a good password?
questions.explanation: A good password should be at least 8 characters long. Longer passwords are more secure as they are harder to guess or brute-force.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is a good tool to use to help enforce the deployment of good passwords?
questions.explanation: A password cracker can be used to test the strength of passwords by attempting to crack them. This tool helps identify weak passwords and enforce the policy of using strong passwords.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is a good time frame for making changes to passwords?
questions.explanation: It is recommended to change passwords every 90 to 120 days to reduce the risk of them being compromised over time.

questions.questionText: Question: You should keep all computer rooms at reasonable humidity levels, which are in between:
questions.explanation: Humidity levels in computer rooms should be kept between 20 - 70 percent to avoid condensation or static buildup that could damage equipment.

questions.questionText: Question: Within a virus, which component is responsible for what the virus does to the victim file?
questions.explanation: The payload of a virus defines what happens to the victim file, such as deleting it, altering its contents, or stealing information.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following can be thought of as the simplest and almost cheapest type of firewall?
questions.explanation: A packet filter firewall is the simplest and most cost-effective type of firewall. It works by filtering packets based on predefined rules but does not inspect the contents of the packet.

questions.questionText: Question: Screening router inspects traffic through examining:
questions.explanation: A packet filter firewall is the simplest and cheapest type of firewall, typically using a screening router to inspect and filter traffic based on predefined rules, specifically examining the message header for network addresses.

questions.questionText: Question: A major portion of what is required to address nonrepudiation is accomplished through the use of:

options.A: Strong methods for authentication and ensuring data validity
options.B: Strong methods for authentication and ensuring data integrity
options.C: Strong methods for authorization and ensuring data integrity
options.D: Strong methods for authentication and ensuring data reliability

questions.explanation: Nonrepudiation is primarily achieved through strong authentication methods and ensuring data integrity, ensuring that both the sender and recipient can trust the authenticity of the information.

questions.questionText: Question: Why is it not preferable for a firewall to treat each network frame or packet in isolation?

options.A: Such a firewall has no way of knowing if any given packet is part of an existing connection, is trying to establish a new connection, or is just a rogue packet.
options.B: Such a firewall is costly to set up.
options.C: Such a firewall is too complicated to maintain.
options.D: Such a firewall is CPU hungry.
options.E: Such a firewall offers poor compatibility.

questions.explanation: Stateless firewalls process each packet independently, unable to track the context of an ongoing connection, which means they cannot discern legitimate traffic from malicious packets.

questions.questionText: Question: Phishing attack works primarily through:

options.F:
File download
G) None of the choices

questions.explanation: Phishing attacks often occur through emails that appear legitimate, with embedded links directing the recipient to fraudulent websites designed to steal personal information.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following types of attack often take advantage of curiosity or greed to deliver malware?
questions.explanation: Gimmes, also known as Trojan Horses, exploit curiosity or greed, often using email attachments that promise something enticing, prompting users to open them and unknowingly infect their systems with malware.

questions.questionText: Question: Gimmes often work through:
questions.explanation: Gimmes, or Trojan Horses, typically arrive as email attachments with enticing offers, tricking recipients into opening them and exposing their system to malware.

questions.questionText: Question: Talking about biometric authentication, which of the following is often considered as a mix of both physical and behavioral characteristics?
questions.explanation: Voice is considered a mix of both physical (sound of the voice) and behavioral (speech patterns) characteristics in biometric authentication.

questions.questionText: Question: Talking about biometric measurement, which of the following measures the percent of invalid users who are incorrectly accepted in?
questions.explanation: The False Accept Rate (FAR) measures the percentage of invalid users who are mistakenly accepted by the biometric system, reflecting a critical performance metric in biometric security.

questions.questionText: Question: As part of the IEEE 802.11 standard ratified in September 1999, WEP uses which stream cipher for confidentiality?

options.F:
RC5
G) None of the choices

questions.explanation: WEP (Wired Equivalent Privacy) uses the RC4 stream cipher for confidentiality and the CRC-32 checksum for integrity as part of the IEEE 802.11 standard.

questions.questionText: Question: As part of the IEEE 802.11 standard ratified in September 1999, WEP uses the CRC-32 checksum for:
questions.explanation: WEP uses the CRC-32 checksum for ensuring data integrity in addition to RC4 for confidentiality.

questions.questionText: Question: Many WEP systems require a key in a relatively insecure format. What format is this?
questions.explanation: WEP systems typically require keys in hexadecimal format, which can be easily guessed if they are based on simple patterns.

questions.questionText: Question: Wi-Fi Protected Access implements the majority of which IEEE standard?
questions.explanation: Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA/WPA2) implements most of the IEEE 802.11i standard, enhancing security over WEP with improvements like TKIP.

questions.questionText: Question: One major improvement in WPA over WEP is the use of a protocol which dynamically changes keys as the system is used. What protocol is this?
questions.explanation: WPA uses the Temporal Key Integrity Protocol (TKIP), which dynamically changes encryption keys to enhance security compared to WEP.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following refers to a symmetric key cipher which operates on fixed-length groups of bits with an unvarying transformation?
questions.explanation: A block cipher is a symmetric key cipher that processes fixed-length blocks of data with an unchanging transformation.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following typically consists of a computer, some real looking data and/or a network site that appears to be part of a production network but which is in fact isolated and well prepared?
questions.explanation: A honeypot is a security resource designed to attract attackers, consisting of a computer or network site that appears legitimate but is isolated and prepared for detection.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is a tool you can use to simulate a big network structure on a single computer?
questions.explanation: Honeyd is a software tool used to simulate a large network structure on a single computer, often for use with honeypots.

questions.questionText: Question: What would be the major purpose of a rootkit?

options.A: To hide evidence from system administrators.
options.B: To encrypt files for system administrators.
options.C: To corrupt files for system administrators.

questions.explanation: The primary purpose of a rootkit is to hide evidence of malicious activity from system administrators, making it difficult to detect unauthorized access or actions.

questions.questionText: Question: Most Trojan horse programs are spread through:
questions.explanation: Most Trojan horse programs are distributed via e-mails, often bundled with malicious attachments that execute harmful actions when opened.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following types of spyware was originally designed for determining the sources of error or for measuring staff productivity?
questions.explanation: Keystroke logging, initially used as a diagnostic tool to measure productivity or errors, is now often used for malicious surveillance as spyware.

questions.questionText: Question: You should know the difference between an exploit and a vulnerability. Which of the following refers to a weakness in the system?
questions.explanation: A vulnerability refers to a weakness in the system, while an exploit refers to a method or tool used to take advantage of that weakness.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is a rewrite of ipfwadm?
questions.explanation: ipchains is a rewrite of the ipfwadm firewall, used in earlier versions of Linux, and it was later superseded by iptables.

questions.questionText: Question: Iptables is based on which of the following frameworks?
questions.explanation: Iptables is based on the Netfilter framework, which provides hooks for intercepting and manipulating network packets in the Linux kernel. It controls packet filtering and NAT (Network Address Translation) within the Linux kernel.

questions.questionText: Question: Cisco IOS based routers perform basic traffic filtering via which of the following mechanisms?
questions.explanation: Cisco IOS-based routers use access control lists (ACLs) to filter traffic on the network edge. These lists can allow or deny traffic based on factors like IP addresses, protocols, and port numbers.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following correctly describes the potential problem of deploying Wi-Fi Protected Access to secure your wireless network?

options.A: Potential compatibility problems with wireless network interface cards.
options.B: Potential compatibility problems with wireless access points.
options.C: Potential performance problems with wireless network interface cards.
options.D: Potential performance problems with wireless access points.

questions.explanation: Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA/WPA2) may cause compatibility issues, especially with older wireless access points that do not support the required WPA standards, even though WPA is designed to work with most wireless network interface cards.

questions.questionText: Question: The Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) were developed by:
questions.explanation: Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) are developed by the U.S. Federal government and are used by nonmilitary government agencies and government contractors. They ensure compliance with specific security and interoperability requirements.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following refers to an important procedure when evaluating database security (choose the BEST answer)?

options.A: Performing vulnerability assessments against the database.
options.B: Performing data check against the database.
options.C: Performing dictionary check against the database.
options.D: Performing capacity check against the database system.

questions.explanation: Vulnerability assessments are essential for evaluating database security. These assessments help identify misconfigurations and known vulnerabilities, improving the overall security posture of the database.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following refers to any authentication protocol that requires two independent ways to establish identity and privileges?
questions.explanation: Two-factor authentication (TFA) involves using two independent factors to verify identity. Commonly, this involves 'something you know' (e.g., password) and 'something you have' (e.g., token), providing stronger security than single-factor authentication.

questions.questionText: Question: In the context of physical access control, what is known as the process of verifying user identities?
questions.explanation: Authentication is the process of verifying the identity of a user, typically using one or more of the following factors: something you know, something you have, or something you are.

questions.questionText: Question: The technique of rummaging through commercial trash to collect useful business information is known as:
questions.explanation: Dumpster diving, or information diving, is the practice of sifting through commercial trash to gather sensitive or useful business information, such as passwords or confidential documents.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following refers to a primary component of corporate risk management with the goal of minimizing the risk of prosecution for software piracy due to the use of unlicensed software?
questions.explanation: A software audit is a key component of corporate risk management that helps organizations ensure they are using legally licensed software and avoid the risk of prosecution for software piracy.

questions.questionText: Question: Talking about application system audit, focus should always be placed on:

options.A: Performance and controls of the system
options.B: The ability to limit unauthorized access and manipulation
options.C: Input of data are processed correctly
options.D: Output of data are processed correctly
options.E: Changes to the system are properly authorized

questions.explanation: An application system audit focuses on ensuring proper system performance, limiting unauthorized access, and verifying the accuracy of both input and output data, as well as ensuring that any system changes are properly authorized.

questions.questionText: Question: A successful risk-based IT audit program should be based on:
questions.explanation: An effective scoring system allows auditors to evaluate and prioritize risks, helping to establish a risk- based audit program. This system ensures that resources are focused on areas with the highest potential impact.

questions.questionText: Question: The use of risk assessment tools for classifying risk factors should be formalized in your IT audit effort through:
questions.explanation: The use of risk assessment tools should be formalized by developing written guidelines. These guidelines help auditors apply consistent and systematic approaches to classifying and managing risks.

questions.questionText: Question: What should be done to determine the appropriate level of audit coverage for an organization's IT environment?

options.A: Determine the company's quarterly budget requirement
options.C: Calculate the company's yearly budget requirement
options.D: Define an effective system upgrade methodology
options.E: Define an effective network implementation methodology

questions.explanation: To determine the appropriate level of audit coverage for the organization's IT environment, defining an effective assessment methodology is essential. This methodology allows for proper prioritization of audit resources and ensures the audit scope aligns with the organization's needs.

questions.questionText: Question: IS audits should be selected through a risk analysis process to concentrate on:

options.A: Those areas of greatest risk and opportunity for improvements
options.B: Those areas of least risk and opportunity for improvements
options.C: Those areas of the greatest financial value
options.D: Areas led by the key people of the organization

questions.explanation:
IS audits should focus on areas with the highest risk and where there is the greatest opportunity for
improvement. The purpose is to identify issues that can impact the organization's efficiency, security, or performance.

questions.questionText: Question: Your final audit report should be issued:

options.A: After an agreement on the observations is reached
options.B: Before an agreement on the observations is reached
options.C: If an agreement on the observations cannot be reached

questions.explanation: The final audit report should only be issued once there is an agreement on the observations. This ensures that the audit findings are validated by the appropriate stakeholders.

questions.questionText: Question: The ability of the internal IS audit function to achieve desired objectives depends largely on:
questions.explanation: The success of an internal IS audit depends largely on the independence of the audit team. Ensuring that the audit team is free from conflicts of interest or undue influence allows them to perform their work objectively and effectively.

questions.questionText: Question: In-house personnel performing IS audits should possess which of the following knowledge and/or skills? (Choose 2):

options.A: Information systems knowledge commensurate with the scope of the IT environment in question
options.B: Sufficient analytical skills to determine root cause of deficiencies in question
options.C: Sufficient knowledge on secure system coding
options.D: Sufficient knowledge on secure platform development
options.E: Information systems knowledge commensurate outside of the scope of the IT environment in question

questions.explanation: Personnel performing IS audits need to have adequate knowledge of the IT environment they are auditing and strong analytical skills to identify the underlying causes of any deficiencies or risks.

questions.questionText: Question: A comprehensive IS audit policy should include guidelines detailing what involvement the internal audit team should have?

options.A: In the development and coding of major OS applications
options.B: In the acquisition and maintenance of major WEB applications
options.C: In the human resource management cycle of the application development project
options.D: In the development, acquisition, conversion, and testing of major applications

questions.explanation: An IS audit policy should outline the role of internal auditors in key stages of application development, acquisition, and testing to ensure that security and controls are embedded throughout the process.

questions.questionText: Question: For application acquisitions with significant impacts, participation of your IS audit team should be encouraged:

options.A: Early in the due diligence stage

questions.explanation: For acquisitions with significant IT impacts, involving the IS audit team early in the due diligence stage helps identify potential risks and controls before proceeding with the acquisition.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following should be seen as one of the most significant factors considered when determining the frequency of IS audits within your organization?

options.B: The income generated by the business function
options.D: The nature and level of risk

questions.explanation: The frequency of IS audits should be based on the level and nature of risk present in the organization's systems. High-risk areas may require more frequent audits to ensure proper controls and security measures are in place.

questions.questionText: Question: Properly planned risk-based audit programs are often capable of offering which of the following benefits?
questions.explanation: Risk-based audit programs enhance both the efficiency and effectiveness of audits by focusing on high- risk areas and ensuring resources are used appropriately to address the most critical issues.

questions.questionText: Question: The sophistication and formality of IS audit programs may vary significantly depending on which of the following factors?
questions.explanation: The complexity and scope of IS audit programs can vary based on the size and complexity of the organization being audited. Larger or more complex organizations require more detailed and formal audit processes.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is one of the most common ways that spyware is distributed?
questions.explanation: Spyware is often distributed as a Trojan horse, where it is bundled with a seemingly harmless program that, once installed, secretly installs the spyware on the user's system.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following is not a good tactic to use against hackers?
questions.explanation: Entrapment involves encouraging someone to commit a crime, which is illegal and unethical. It is not a good tactic for dealing with hackers. Enticement, on the other hand, is the practice of luring a hacker into a "honey pot," which can be used for gathering intelligence without directly encouraging illegal behavior.

questions.questionText: Question: Creating which of the following is how a hacker can ensure his ability to return to the hacked system at will?
questions.explanation: A backdoor is a method for a hacker to bypass normal authentication procedures and gain access to a system. It allows them to return to the system at will without being detected.

questions.questionText: Question: A Trojan horse simply cannot operate autonomously.
questions.explanation: A Trojan horse requires the user to invoke the malicious code, meaning it cannot operate by itself without user interaction. It is disguised as a legitimate program or file.

questions.questionText: Question: Which of the following refers to the collection of policies and procedures for implementing controls capable of restricting access to computer software and data files?
questions.explanation: Logical access control refers to the policies and procedures designed to limit access to computer systems.
